report_title: Industry at a Glance: Audio & Video Equipment Distributors
executive_summary: Audio and video equipment distributors wholesale and distribute household-type audio and visual equipment, like cameras and stereos, along with various media players and sound systems. As these items are mostly discretionary purchases, fluctuations in disposable income and unemployment levels determine revenue. Over the five years to 2023, as income has increased, consumers have invested more into higher-quality TV sets and robust home entertainment systems. Supply chain disruptions and establishment closures due to the pandemic resulted in significant reductions in both demand and the number of establishments. Increased competition from substitute products and online retailers has also

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As a result, industry revenue is expected to decline at a CAGR of 2.2% to $45.1 billion over the five years to 2023. Revenue is also enduring threats from inflation and recessionary fears in the current year. Revenue is expected to fall 2.4% in 2023 as demand remains high following the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Many Industry Products Have Become Obsolete
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry also offers many products that are becoming obsolete. These products include dedicated media playing devices like DVD and CD players, stereos, tape players, VCRs and video cameras. Audio and video equipment distributors continue to contend with increased competition from substitute products, as all smartphones are equipped with high-definition cameras and streaming has become more popular than physical media.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Created Significant Supply Chain Disruption
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Severe supply chain disruptions amid the initial outbreak of COVID-19 made it difficult for distributors to acquire goods from manufacturers. A rise in the unemployment rate and added regulations forced many retailers to temporarily close, limiting orders from downstream

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Operators Were Forced to Restructure to Improve Profitability
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While the industry has experienced unfavorable demand conditions, the number of distributors in this industry has risen slowly. At the same time, the number of has fallen, suggesting companies have been downsizing by shutting down less profitable locations. Large companies have been forced to sustain themselves by closing some of their smaller local and regional stores, which has contributed to the decline in employment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Revenue from audio and visual equipment distribution is expected to rise at a CAGR of 0.5% to $46.4 billion over the five years to 2028, when profit margins are estimated to equal 3.5%.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Smartphones Continue to Threaten the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, the number of internet connections is expected to continue rising. The continued importance of the internet and smartphones has been making many industry products like DVD players and cameras obsolete, as these new technologies contain all of the functions of the old products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: An Increase in Demand Will Help Companies Combat Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To distinguish themselves from external competition, distributors will increasingly attempt to repackage their goods in order to make products more appealing and attractive to customers. Greater specialization will boost revenue, as vital downstream markets, like designers and businesses, will likely rely on distributors as a single point of contact for a range of brands and options.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Consumer Trend Toward Energy-Efficient Devices is Expected to Continue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With consumers becoming increasingly aware of their energy consumption, carbon footprint and waste output, manufacturers have developed environmentally friendly products, which are being increasingly stocked by wholesalers and sold to retail outlets.

industry_definition: This industry wholesales and distributes household-type audio and visual equipment, such as cameras and stereos. TVs, media players and sound systems are examples of products that this industry distributes.

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: medium - steady

key_trends: The mainstream adoption of smartphones has consistently represented a significant source of external competition for the industry
By selling niche products to resellers, industry operators have been able to command higher profit
Industry operators rely on the ability to purchase goods in bulk from manufacturers and sell at a slightly higher price to their clients
Despite the strong recovery from the pandemic in 2021 and 2022, incomes are expected to rise at a slower pace amid slower anticipated economic growth
The consumer trend toward energy-efficient devices is expected to continue over the five years to 2028

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment is generally divided into both large and independent retailers. Large retailers include mass merchandisers, department stores and electronics franchises. Independent retailers consist of privately owned consumer electronics and camera stores. Consistent demand from independent audio and visual equipment stores during the five-year period upheld this segment's portion of revenue. As many retailers lost significant revenue when they closed during the pandemic, weakening their purchasing ability.
The other wholesaler and reseller markets contain value-added resellers, which package and partner products like audio equipment before marketing this assortment as home or car entertainment systems.

Businesses, like hotels and restaurants, also source audio and visual equipment through wholesalers. Whereas wholesale bypass, a process in which manufacturers forego wholesale distributors and sell directly to retailers or consumers, is common in the retail markets. Industry wholesalers offer extensive product and brand variety with the ease of dealing with one point of contact.
Businesses, like hotels and restaurants, also source audio and visual equipment through wholesalers.

Residential building contractors include professional contractors, who purchase audio and visual equipment for home construction and other renovation projects. This segment's share of industry revenue has experienced fluctuations due to changes in the value of residential construction.

products_and_services.product_description: TVs have weakened as a source of revenue. The TV segment share of revenue has weakened over the years to 2023, despite evolving technology, like 4K Ultra HD, Smart TVs and 3D TVs.

Audio equipment includes radios, stereos, CD players, speakers and related accessories. This product line is enduring struggles, as industry products are being made obsolete by smartphones, the internet and other new devices.

products_and_services.product_or_service: DVD players, VCRs and video cameras
products_and_services.product_description: Video equipment includes DVD players, VCRs, video cameras and other related accessories. This product line has declined significantly during the current period.

tier_1_suppliers: Audio & Video Equipment Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Consumer Electronics Stores in the US
Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US
tier_2_buyers: Storage & Warehouse Leasing in the US
Long-Distance Freight Trucking in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: During the past decade, demand from the retail segment has been negatively affected by manufacturers vertically integrating their own distribution networks into their businesses and suppling directly to retailers and consumers.

Audio and video equipment distribution is reliant on the construction and homebuilding markets. When residential construction increases, consumers tend to make increased purchases of industry goods such as TVs, speakers and home entertainment systems.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports and exports accounted at manufacturing level
international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports and exports of the Audio and Video Equipment Distributors industry are accounted for at the manufacturing level, but not at the wholesale level.

business_locations.location_description: The Western region has the highest concentration of industry establishments, around 30% of the total establishments, while its population percentage is around 20%.

The Southeast region is the second most concentrated, primarily in Florida, which accounts for 11.3% of industry establishments, alone. This region has the greatest concentration of consumer electronics retail stores in the United States.

The mid-Atlantic region houses major corporate hubs like New York City and Washington, D.C. These centers of commerce require top-notch audio and video equipment for presentations, conferences, and communication.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Wholesalers that only sell to other businesses are required to obtain a wholesaler's license from the US Department of Revenue.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Families First Coronavirus Response Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: This act required employers to provide workers with paid sick leave or expanded family and medical leave for reasons related to the coronavirus.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Life Cycle Stage: decline, Industry Assistance Level: low - steady, Competition Level: high - steady
Capital Intensity Level: low, Concentration Level: low, Regulation Level: light - steady, Globalization Level: low - steady
Licensing fees and government regulations make it difficult for new companies to enter the industry.
Sizeable upfront investments and resource constraints can create additional barriers.

basis_points.basis_description: The Audio and Video Equipment Distributors industry experiences a high level of internal competition. Little production differentiation implies industry operators must compete mainly on price to remain competitive in the audio and visual equipment distribution market.
The ability to provide an extensive product range within a subsegment is a huge advantage for distributors in this industry since it provides a one-stop shop for retailers.
In addition to competing among themselves, operators also compete with e-commerce and other methods of mitigating costs.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry covers a wide array of products, from professional audio equipment to home theater systems.
The audio-visual landscape caters to diverse customer demands, ranging from professionals seeking studio equipment to individuals looking for home entertainment setups.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase costs rise with new technology
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Over the five years to 2023, purchase expenses have risen due to higher costs of advanced technology.
Warehouse operators typically do not require a large volume of human labor for daily tasks.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital expenditures have remained fairly steady over the past decade.
The industry requires experienced workers to perform daily tasks.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Advancements in technology are blurring the lines between traditional audio and video equipment and their digital counterparts.
The reliance on global supply chains for components exposes the industry to disruptions like COVID-19.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Technological developments have largely centered on the computerized automation of inventory control.
This industry has experienced an increase in the use of electronic ordering systems.

FAQs.question: How have your sales been affected by the growth of online shopping?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers and online retailers selling products directly to consumers are lowering sales for independent consumer electronics stores.

FAQs.question: What assistance did the industry receive from the CARES Act during the COVID-19 pandemic?
FAQs.answer: As part of the CARES Act, many small businesses received economic relief.

FAQs.question: Does the industry receive private assistance?
FAQs.answer: The audio and visual equipment distribution industry does not receive significant private assistance.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on any one market or major customer?
FAQs.answer: Industry wholesalers have revenue streams from a few markets.

FAQs.question: How do you manage volatile demand from economic conditions or seasonality?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers counteract downturns by increasingly selling sought-after products.

FAQs.question: How does company size affect profitability and growth potential?
FAQs.answer: Larger wholesalers typically buy in larger quantities, leading to lower purchasing costs.

FAQs.question: How has technology been implemented in the purchasing process?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers have computerized inventory control systems.

FAQs.question: How are increased digitalization and online shopping affecting financial performance?
What is your company policy on hazardous material handling?
How have you adjusted to new regulations over the past decade?
FAQs.answer: All they need is a wholesaling license.

FAQs.question: How is ongoing inflation affecting your business?
FAQs.answer: Companies will likely contend with rising input prices.

FAQs.question: What cost-saving measures do you currently employ?
Do you have contacts with key distributors and end users?
FAQs.answer: It's important for wholesalers to develop strong relationships.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain optimum stock levels?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers must have sufficient stock levels.

FAQs.question: Are you keeping up with the latest trends?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers must be able to cycle through inventory quickly.

FAQs.question: Do you find that revenue trends in line with the number of households?
FAQs.answer: With more occupied housing units, demand will likely grow.

FAQs.question: How are you affected by an increase in the number of mobile internet connections?
FAQs.answer: Mainstream adoption of smartphones has represented competition.

FAQs.question: How did your company fare amid the pandemic's economic climate?
FAQs.answer: Wholesale demand fell during periods of low disposable income.
